DOCNAME: CASE OF McCALLUM v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 8 - Right to respect for private and family life (Article 8-1 - Respect for correspondence);Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG On DATE Mr PERSON , who had previously been dealt with by the courts and served sentences of imprisonment on a number of occasions , was convicted by ORG of GPE of assault and robbery . He was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment , to run from CARDINAL DATE .

Following his conviction , he was initially allocated to ORG . In DATE he was transferred to ORG , because of the serious disruptive effect which he was having on other prisoners . Whilst in custody he lost CARDINAL days’ remission of sentence for a series of offences against prison discipline . He was released from prison on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG During the course of his sentence , PERSON spent CARDINAL periods in ORG ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , the first from CARDINAL DATE to DATE and the second from DATE to CARDINAL DATE . The second period exceeded the usual CARDINAL months’ maximum in view of his particularly uncooperative attitude whilst he was there .

Both transfers to the ORG followed periods of bad behaviour on the part of the applicant , involving notably assaults on and abuse of staff . In each case it was considered that the transfer could benefit both him and the general situation in FAC .
CARDINAL . ORG During DATE and DATE , the prison authorities imposed the following particular restrictions on the applicant ’s correspondence .

( a ) CARDINAL letters from the applicant , one to his solicitor and CARDINAL to a Member of ORG and each dated DATE , were stopped in accordance with Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(d ) and Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) , respectively ( prohibitions on complaints about prison treatment ; see paragraph CARDINAL ( a ) and ( b ) below ) .

( b ) A letter of CARDINAL DATE from the applicant to the editor of ORG , asking for a copy of an article in that newspaper concerning the applicant ( " Cage Man Euro Court Plea " ) and enquiring if CARDINAL previous letters had been received , was stopped . The prison authorities considered that the letter did not conform to Standing Orders , but there is no record of the grounds for this view .

( c ) A letter dated DATE from the applicant to ORG was stopped because it contained allegations of assault on other prisoners , who had not themselves complained through any internal or external channel . The letter was regarded as objectionable in terms of Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(d ) ; the authorities also considered that to allow letters complaining on behalf of other prisoners would be contrary to good order and discipline . PERSON was allowed to write another letter containing allegations of assault concerning himself alone .

( d ) A letter dated DATE from the applicant to Miss PERSON of ORG was stopped on the grounds that she was not a previous correspondent of his , nor a legal adviser for the purposes of his petition to ORG ) and PERSON ) ; see paragraph CARDINAL ( d ) and ( c ) below ) .

( e ) Letters dated DATE from the applicant to his representative Mr PERSON were delayed and eventually posted on DATE . The Government had agreed that PERSON could , pursuant to Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(g)(i ) , correspond with PERSON in relation to his application to the Commission , on the understanding that Mr PERSON would abide by the ORG ’s rules of confidentiality . Some particulars of the applicant ’s complaints had appeared in the press and ORG was unwilling to allow further letters without an assurance from PERSON that he would comply with the rules in the future . After the ORG had received such an assurance , the letters in question were posted .

( f ) Copies of letters written by PERSON to ORG on DATE and to the Secretary of ORG on CARDINAL DATE were withheld from the applicant under Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL ( d ) below ) . The letters suggested that there had been a breakdown of discipline on the part of the staff at ORG and predicted disturbances among prisoners ; the second letter also implied that staff might have been responsible for causing a fire in the applicant ’s cell . The prison Governor considered the letters objectionable on the grounds of good order and discipline , fearing in particular that prisoners might be encouraged to make the disturbances predicted if the letters came into their hands .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG imposed on the applicant a disciplinary award which included an absolute prohibition for DATE on all correspondence , pursuant to Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Prison ( GPE ) Rules DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . On DATE the Secretary of ORG for GPE , to whose attention the terms of this prohibition had been drawn , ruled that it was not to affect Mr PERSON ’s correspondence relating to his application to the ORG or his correspondence with his Member of ORG , the Procurator Fiscal or his legal adviser .

CARDINAL . ORG At the relevant time the prison system in GPE was governed by ORG " LAW " ) , sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of which vested general control and superintendance over prisons in GPE in the Secretary of ORG for GPE . He was empowered , by DATE , to commit prisoners to such prison as might be appointed by rules made under LAW and to transfer prisoners from CARDINAL prison to another and , by section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , to " make [ by statutory instrument ] rules for the regulation and management of prisons ... and for the classification , treatment , employment , discipline and control of persons required to be detained therein " .

In exercise of his powers under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , the Secretary of ORG made the ORG ( GPE ) Rules DATE ( " the Prison Rules " ) , which have been amended from time to time . He also , in supplement of ORG and by virtue of his general jurisdiction over prisons and of various powers conferred by LAW themselves , issues instructions to the Governors of prisons in the form of ORG and administrative circulars .
LAW and the Prison Rules apply to ORG , as do most of the Standing Orders and administrative circulars . There are also administrative instructions particular to the Unit .
CARDINAL . ORG Rule CARDINAL of the Prison Rules empowers the Secretary of ORG to " set aside particular prisons or parts of prisons for particular classes of prisoners or for particular purposes " .

ORG was set up in DATE to provide a secure place of segregation for those prisoners who , through their violent or subversive behaviour , seriously disrupt the establishments in which they are accommodated , who had not responded to the forms of treatment available there and who flagrantly refuse to cooperate in the normal prison routine . The ORG also offers a special level of protection for staff .

Transfer to the ORG , which is not employed as a punishment , is intended to remove a threat to the good order and discipline of the transferring prison , to provide relief for staff there and to achieve an improvement in the prisoner ’s attitude .

CARDINAL . ORG The ORG is used sparingly , prisoners being transferred there only when the facilities available elsewhere are considered ineffective . It is not used to capacity and has lain empty on a number of occasions . It was closed in DATE but re - opened in DATE .

Authority to transfer prisoners to the ORG is given personally by the Secretary of ORG for GPE or another NORP Office Minister , upon the recommendation of both the Governor of the transferring prison and the prison administration division of ORG and after consultation of ORG . Except in case of crisis or emergency , transfers are normally effected only after thorough consideration of the particular circumstances .
No prisoner will be detained in the ORG longer than is considered necessary . No minimum period is prescribed ; the maximum will not exceed DATE , save in exceptional circumstances .

CARDINAL . ORG The progress of each prisoner detained in the ORG is constantly monitored by its staff , who report DATE to the prison administration division of ORG . Each case is also examined DATE by ORG , which may make recommendations to the Secretary of ORG for the individual ’s transfer out of the ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG The ORG comprises CARDINAL single cells of QUANTITY in total area , to which prisoners are confined except for exercise periods , toileting , visits and authorised interviews . They are not permitted to associate with other prisoners .

The area in which the prisoner is confined , measuring QUANTITY by QUANTITY , is separated from the cell ’s entrance lobby by a security grille , designed to protect staff . The area in question is larger than the minimum recommended for a single cell in a security prison . The lighting , heating and ventilation of cells in the Unit are comparable or superior to those in separate cell areas in other prisons and to those in many ordinary cells in other prisons .
CARDINAL . ORG Letters and visits are allowed on the basis normal in prisons in accordance with ORG and ORG . Unit visits normally take place at DATE and can be extended TIME .

CARDINAL . ORG Library books and newspapers are provided on the normal prison basis , prisoners being free to purchase additional materials out of their own funds . Piped radio facilities are provided in each cell and notebooks are made available in accordance with ORG . Prisoners already taking correspondence courses are encouraged to continue .

CARDINAL . Meals are taken and paid work , when available , is carried out by ORG inmates in their cells . Exercise is provided for them for TIME periods DATE , but not in association with other prisoners .

CARDINAL . ORG In addition to visits from friends and relatives , prisoners in the ORG are visited by the Governor and the Chief Officer of ORG DATE , by the ORG chaplain and a psychiatrist DATE and by ORG on request .
CARDINAL . ORG Rule CARDINAL of ORG provides , inter alia :

" ( CARDINAL ) Every prisoner shall be allowed to write and to receive a letter on his admission , and shall thereafter be allowed to write and receive letters and to receive visits at intervals laid down by the Secretary of ORG . The intervals so prescribed may be extended as a punishment for misconduct , but shall not be extended so as to preclude a prisoner from writing and receiving a letter , and receiving a visit , DATE .

( CARDINAL ) Subject to the provisions of Rule CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) every letter to or from a prisoner shall be read by the Governor or by an officer deputed by him for that purpose and it shall be within the discretion of the Governor to stop any letter if he considers that the contents are objectionable . "
CARDINAL . ORG At the relevant time , these provisions were supplemented by various Standing Orders , of which the following were pertinent in the present case .
( a ) Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) dealt with the exercise of the Governor ’s discretion under LAW ) to stop " objectionable " letters . It stated :

" All ordinary matter , including news of public events , should be passed . Comment by a prisoner on his own conviction and sentence is not objectionable if expressed in proper terms . Objectionable matter falls within narrow limits , viz.-
( d ) Complaints of prison treatment . These should be addressed to the Secretary of ORG or ORG by petition .

( b ) Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) dealt with the conditions governing the contents of letters to Members of ORG . It provided that such letters should be sent , after being read , " except where they include a complaint or request concerning prison treatment , including allegations against prison staff , which has not completed the prescribed procedure for remedying the grievance i.e. by petition to the Secretary of ORG or other appropriate official means " .
( c ) Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) related to petitions by inmates to the ORG and included the following passage :
" ( g ) If the question of legal advice arises it will be dealt with as under :
( i ) a prisoner may correspond with his legal adviser and with other persons in connection with the preparation of the petition to the Commission on the same basis as if he were an appellant .

( d ) Standing Order Ic CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provided , with certain savings , that prisoners would be allowed to correspond with " close relations " and normally also with " other relatives and existing friends " . The Order also contained the following passages :

" ( b ) ... Governors have discretion to forbid [ letters in the second category ] ... on the grounds of security or good order and discipline or in the interests of the prevention or discouragement of crime .
( c ) Governors have discretion to allow communication with other persons not personally known to the prisoner before he came into custody . ... "

CARDINAL . ORG In addition to a complaint to the Governor of the prison , a prisoner in GPE who is aggrieved by his treatment has available to him various remedies . They fall into the following CARDINAL categories :
( a ) internal channels of complaint , namely :
( i ) a petition to the Secretary of ORG for GPE ; ( ii ) a complaint to ORG ; ( iii ) a complaint to a ORG of the FAC ; ( iv ) representations to ORG ; ( v ) representations to ORG ;
( b ) an investigation by the Parliamentary Commissioner for ORG ;
( c ) judicial remedies .

Particulars concerning the remedies listed at ( a ) ( i ) and ( ii ) and ( b ) appear in the ORG ’s PERSON and PERSON judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , at pp . CARDINAL , paras . CARDINAL - CARDINAL . An indication of those referred to at ( a ) ( iii)-(v ) is given at paragraph CARDINAL of the Commission ’s report in the present case . Judicial remedies are of the following CARDINAL kinds .
CARDINAL . ORG A prisoner aggrieved by prison conditions may challenge them by the ordinary remedies of private law as an infringement of his civil rights .

It was emphasised by ORG in PERSON v. Honey ( [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL and [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL ) that " a convicted prisoner , in spite of his imprisonment , retains all civil rights which are not taken away expressly or by necessary implication " . Thus , the general principle of NORP law that a person has a right not to be subjected , deliberately or negligently , to physical or mental harm remains applicable to a prisoner . For example , he can bring an action against the Secretary of ORG seeking declarator and damages in respect of an alleged assault by prison staff or in respect of harm to his physical or mental health allegedly suffered as a result of unduly rigorous or inhumane conditions ( see , inter alia , GPE v. Chief Constable of GPE ( DATE ) , ORG , DATE ) .

The Government cited a number of authorities in support of the proposition that treatment of prisoners which is so inhuman or degrading that it can not be regarded as having been authorised by ORG will be unlawful and actionable as a civil wrong . In the context of correspondence , they stated that a restriction that infringed a right retained by a prisoner , such as his right of access to a legal adviser relating to possible civil proceedings , would be considered to be unlawful ( NORP v. Home Secretary , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] ORG Reports CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The exercise by public authorities of statutory powers and duties is subject to judicial review . The grounds on which such review may be open are in substance the same in GPE as in GPE and GPE ( see PERSON v. ORG , DATE ORG CARDINAL , per Lord PERSON at CARDINAL ) . In particular , an exercise of discretionary power may be challenged on the grounds that the authority concerned has acted arbitrarily , in bad faith , unreasonably , for an improper purpose or otherwise outside its statutory powers ( see , for example , the speech of Lord PERSON in ORG Unions v. Minister for ORG [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL at CARDINAL and [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL at CARDINAL - CARDINAL , as quoted in the DATE judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , para . CARDINAL ) . In GPE , the supervisory jurisdiction over public authorities is exercised by ORG , which can grant a wide range of remedies , including the annulment of any unlawful decision and the award of damages in appropriate conditions .

A prisoner aggrieved by prison conditions can in principle bring an application to the supervisory jurisdiction to establish that the Secretary of ORG had failed to perform the duties incumbent on him or that his decision to institute or maintain those conditions was unreasonable . Thus in NORP v. Home Secretary , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL Weekly Law Reports DATE and PERSON v. Secretary of ORG for GPE DATE ORG CARDINAL applications for judicial review were brought by prisoners aggrieved by conditions in prisons to which they had been transferred . Likewise , a prisoner may challenge a restriction upon his correspondence as ultra vires in that it infringed his civil rights or as unreasonable , and such a challenge can be brought whether the restriction has been imposed by the Secretary of ORG ( NORP v. Home Secretary , ex parte PERSON , cited above ) , the prisoner Governor ( PERSON v. Deputy Governor of ORG [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ) or ORG in the exercise of disciplinary powers ( NORP v. ORG , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] ORG Reports CARDINAL ) .
